10.02 a.m.
FIRST SCHEDULE


    Head 11-

    Mr Lim Choon Mong (Serangoon): Mr Speaker, Sir, on this question of defence services, I think we must take a very realistic view of the whole matter. In our London talks, we agreed that defence and external affairs, excepting for trade and cultural relations, should be left to Britain. Therefore, Sir, defence is not within our province. We do realise that, for purposes of internal security, we require armed support, but to expend a total of $13,926,370, which forms 5 per cent of our total revenue, is, I think, unrealistic.

    I have heard that the Government is going to hand over the Navy to the Federation of Malaya. If it is to be handed over in the near future, I do not see why we should expend such a large sum as $5 million odd for its development. Perhaps it may be said that this expenditure is recurrent but I think that all development, anything requiring more money to bring the Navy up to a greater standard, should be stopped.

    I have said during the Second Reading of the Appropriation Bill that it is not a fighting navy that we want but a merchant navy. It is not fighting men who would be required to protect Singapore, but men of the merchant marine, people who would be able to help us in supplying service to the world and developing our own shipping lines.

    In this age, it is ridiculous to develop a navy. Today the world has developed weapons of war to such a high standard that it is impossible for a navy, consisting of so many minesweepers and probably no destroyers, to go against big

Column: 3084

powers. What we depend on for our safety would be collective security. We will have to depend on friendly nations, on being friendly to everybody, and on the justice of the world to keep this island safe.

    The second point is expenditure on the army. This comes up to $3 million odd with another $2.8 million making it $5 million odd again. I would say that we require a regiment or two to assist our police but I would suggest that the money expended in this direction should not just be spent in maintaining fighting men, but in teaching a trade to the youths who are out of school and are unemployed. They should join the armed forces, just as the British army does, and when these servicemen come out, they are skilled tradesmen. If the army is run on this basis, we will not be wasting our army; we will be using the army as a sort of school to help our young people be useful to society when they come out.

    In this matter, I think that voluntary services should be encouraged, and that any money expended should only be a bare minimum to maintain the fighting forces, the rest being devoted to ways of training the young servicemen of Singapore.

    As to the air force, there is nothing much to talk about. We have spent a lot of money on it but have only produced a few people holding private licences. Here again, we should look forward not to producing a fighting force, but a force of young people able to help us man our own air lines should we require them later.

    We can take a line from the big nations, Sir, especially Britain. In time of war, when we do really require armed forces, we usually find that there is an insufficiency of personnel in the regular forces. In such cases, those in the merchant navy can be asked to serve the country in transportation, shipping and other work, and those in the commercial air lines to do likewise. If we develop our armed forces in this way, I think it will help Singapore.

    The Government would probably wonder about the fact that we have no airline, merchant navy and so on. The point is that we must start somewhere.

Column: 3085

If we have the personnel, then it would be possible to see these things take shape. At least those who want to start shipping lines or air lines would be able to find skilled men to operate them.

    Sir, I think that this defence expenditure, which forms about 5 per cent of our total revenue, is a bit unrealistic.

    Mr R. Jumabhoy (Telok Ayer): Mr Speaker, Sir, I want to lay further stress in addition to what I said yesterday. Britain has taken upon itself the defence of the Colony. The Hongkong naval base is being abolished and Britain is definitely going to retain the naval base here. Therefore I must stress that our workers in that area should not fear at all about unemployment. What they have to see is that the climate will be favourable for the base to remain here, that it is not removed somewhere else. Well, that is politics; it is left to their votes to decide.

    I talked about the present advancing age of sputniks and missiles. Singapore is a small place and can in no case defend itself. I will quote three examples. Korea was attacked or there was trouble there. There was also trouble in Indo-China; and Egypt was attacked by Britain and France. What happened? The United Nations came to their help and brought peace. Such big countries have to depend on other nations to put things right if they are attacked. How big is Singapore after all? Should we then spend so much money on such services?

    What is needed, I stress again, are internal security forces to help the police, and a strong marine police with speed-boats to prevent smuggling of contraband. This is very essential but it does not mean that we should spend millions on the capital and other cost of a Royal Malayan Navy. I shall come to it later.

    Sir, we do need to train pilots, and an auxiliary air force may be maintained on a limited scale. The Flying Club could be helped. But it is very unnecessary to keep these at the expense of the taxpayer. Besides, we may be supporting imperial designs, letting our boys become fodder for some imperial design. We should prevent that.

Column: 3086



10.15 a.m.

    The Acting Chief Secretary (Mr S. T. Stewart): Mr Speaker, Sir, the expenditure on defence services represents, as the hon. Member for Serangoon says, about 5 per cent of the total expenditure including that on development. By almost any standard, I suggest that this is a low proportion and is not, as the hon. Member says, unrealistic.

    Sir, the attitude that in this age of sputniks, we on a small island like Singapore should drop all plans for defence, would appear to be a negative one. There are still conventional forms of warfare and aggression. True, Sir, Singapore does not maintain defence services to attack anyone, but we do need these services to have our own local forces and build them up for good reasons, especially to safeguard internal security, to help the police in the maintenance of law and order should the necessity arise.

    I would also submit, Sir, that if Singapore looks forward to merger with the Federation of Malaya, it would reasonably be expected to contribute towards the common defence. Defence forces cannot be built up overnight.

    Sir, with regard to the Royal Malayan Navy, the Pan-Malayan background of the building up of this force by Singapore was ably given by Sir William Goode when he was Chief Secretary in last year's Assembly debate on the 1957 Estimates. I would refer the hon. Members for Telok Ayer and Serangoon to columns 862 to 866 of the Official Report, Volume 2, No. 12, of 21st November, 1956. The future of the R.M.N., Sir, is still under discussion with the Federation, and I am sure Members will not expect me to give too much detailed information about it, when these negotiations are still being carried on.

    Some members said that external defence is a matter for the British Government. In the case of the navy, strategic defence would certainly be a matter for the United Kingdom Government, but we would surely have to see to our own inshore defences, to keep our waters clear, because Singapore is a port. The navy would have a peacetime role also to maintain. The R.M.N. also has Emergency duties to perform; and one of

Column: 3087

the lighter roles which it has recently played is, for instance, to convey citizenship registration teams to Christmas Island. The R.M.N. has a peacetime role. Whatever the outcome of the negotiations with the Federation, we would require to have some ships.

    With regard to the armed forces, that is the regular Battalion and the other military forces, I think Members will agree that the expenditure on them is not at all large, if we take into consideration the necessity - which this Assembly has approved - of raising an infantry Battalion and providing also for a part-time battalion of the Singapore military forces supported by ancillary units. The role which these Singapore military forces can play in supporting the police in internal security is certainly very important, and I think any expenditure in that direction is justified.

    I think it was the Member for Telok Ayer who mentioned about the army, sea and air cadet corps. With more than half of the population of Singapore under 21 years of age, it cannot be doubted that money spent on these cadet corps, which are really a form of youth movement and extra-mural activity in schools, is money well spent. Although the corps are provided for under the head "Defence", the emphasis is more on corporate discipline, comradeship and self-reliance than on purely-

    Mr R. Jumabhoy rose -

    The Chairman: Is it a point of order?

    Mr R. Jumabhoy: Of explanation, Sir

    The Chairman: The Hon. the Chief Secretary has not given way.

    Mr Stewart: - military matters.

    Sir, with regard to the Malayan Auxiliary Air Force, the policy is to shift the emphasis from the flying side to the fighter control unit, which has a real part to play in the defence of Malaya as a whole, it being their job to man radar reporting stations in an emergency. We hope that the Singapore

Column: 3088

section of the M.A.A.F. will one day be part of a pan-Malayan air force. As Members perhaps are already aware, the Federation is developing a regular air force and we hope that one day our section of the Singapore M.A.A.F. will contribute to that air force.

    Other items under Head 11, Defence Services, were not raised, and I presume that these have met with the approval of Members. I would say that we wish nothing but peace to all but we must have local forces to safeguard our internal security and support the police in maintaining law and order within our borders which, by virtue of the fact that we are an island, include large tracts of sea.

    Mr R. Jumabhoy: Mr Speaker, Sir, I never said that we should prevent our youths being trained as cadets on a voluntary basis. I was hitting at the expenditure on the Royal Malayan Navy costing $5,082,000, as appearing on page 98 of the Estimates, and the arguments put by the Hon. the Chief Secretary are very, very lame indeed. To help in the registration of citizens on Christmas Island - how many citizens are there on that island? Could lie not manage by chartering a small boat? Do you want $5 million to spend on that?

    The Chairman: Please address the Chair.

    Mr R. Jumabhoy: Then, Sir, the argument was, 'Oh, we have to think about our neighbour.' Well, what about thinking about our own taxpayers? Have we not to think about those who have to foot the bill? I know the Government is incapable of taking things into its own hands and that it is just following a policy already laid down by the Colonial Office.

    The Chief Minister (Dr Lim Yew Hock): Mr Speaker, Sir, such a cold day and at such an early time, yet the debate is already getting heated up!

    The Royal Malayan Navy was brought into force years and years ago, as explained last year, as part of the defence strategy for the whole of Malaya-Singapore to put up a navy, the Federation of Malaya an army. The

Column: 3089

navy has been with us and I am sure it is not suggested that it should be scrapped.

    Mr R. Jumabhoy: Scrap it!

    The Chief Minister: Ah, not so simple! That is what we are trying to do and what we hope to achieve is that the navy could be transferred to the Federation of Malaya. There have been negotiations between us and the Federation as to when and how this navy should be transferred.

    So far, the attack on the defence services has come from the Liberal-Socialist Party. We have one Member who criticised us violently and said that there should be no defence services, whereas we have the leader of that Party saying, 'Let us tackle the subject in its right perspective.' He would like to see more regiments; he would like to see an army but not a navy. But he went to the extern of saying that the 5 per cent of the total revenue of Singapore to be spent on defence services is much too much and out of all proportion when we face the facts. But he did urge that there should be more regiments. At the present time, we only have one battalion. A second battalion is awaiting the result of the transfer of the Royal Malayan Navy to the Federation. If we are going to have more than one battalion, I would like the hon. Member to take note that the 5 per cent criticised by him may be 7 per cent in due course!

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: Sir, I think I would like one or two points of clarification. We have an army and a navy, to be built up from the revenues of Singapore. How much control have we got over this navy and army? If I understand it rightly, they should be under the control of the British Commander-in-Chief. We have heard that the army and the navy have rendered useful service, at ceremonies and so on. I am sure we do not deny the Chief Minister the opportunity of inspecting the navy and army - these are more pleasant jobs. But the real role of the army, as I said, is assisting our police for purposes of internal security, and if there is such a need to do so, would it be under the command of the Chief Minister or the

Column: 3090

British C-in-C? That is what I would like to be clear about.

    On expenditure, I would say that if we have just sufficient armed forces to assist the police on internal security, we need not spend so much money. I would like the Chief Minister to understand that my view, as far as the Royal Malayan Navy is concerned, is to stop everything that will incur more expenditure. Wait for the day you hand over the whole thing to the Federation of Malaya.

    Probably the navy, as I understand, may be performing one or two duties but we would very much like to see one or two of our ships stationed within our own territorial waters so that when neighbours come along with gunboats and pinch our boats, then our navy could stand up with their water-pistols and say, "Here, we have a water-pistol against your cannon."

    I would very much like to see some realistic work done if we think about building up an army, air force, radar network and so on. If we do not expend enough to have a big fighter force and a big army, then we may only be able to plot the places where the bombs will fall and not be in a position to stop them falling.

10.30 a.m.

    All this work is very good, very well explained and so on, but I think every cent that we put up on these defence services means a cent saved by the United Kingdom. I would like the Government to know that defence is still in the hands of Britain. The less we spend on it, the more the U.K. will have to spend; the more we spend on it, the more the U.K. will be able to direct our own army, navy and so-called air force.

    The Chief Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, a little knowledge is indeed a dangerous thing. The defence forces of Singapore are controlled by the local Government. It is only for the purpose of discipline that they come under the British Commander-in-Chief.

    The hon. Member said that if we have local defence forces of that nature, the Chief Minister can have a pleasant

Column: 3091

job inspecting them. I consider that it is not only a pleasant job but a proud moment of my life when I can inspect local people answering the call and standing up saying, "This is our country. We are here to defend it!" Those would be the proudest moments of my life.

    The Member says that defence is still in the hands of the United Kingdom Government. It is external defence and not internal security. It has been explained to hon. Members that our local defence forces are primarily for internal security.

    Apart from that, I am sure the hon. Member is not suggesting that we should be content with our new Constitution and rest content with just self-government. How are we going to demand independence if we do not start building defence forces of our own? How are we going to seek a merger with the Federation of Malaya when the Federation has defence forces of its own and we have nothing to contribute towards the common defence?

    The Minister for Commerce and Industry (Mr J. M. Jumabhoy): Just a word in edgewise, Sir, and that is that perhaps the hon. Member for Serangoon forgets that if we do not have detachments of the local forces, then the Liberal-Socialists in the City Council cannot be sure of getting a march-past for the President to take the salute, which is none of the functions of the City Council Or perhaps they are not interested because in any case they do not hope to capture the City Council?

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: Sir, I would like a point of clarification. If we want to merge with the Federation of Malaya, we do not have to go in with our guns at the ready; we go in with a friendly attitude. There is no need to have an army in order to capture the Federation. In fact if the Federation feels like it, it could send in an army and we would be finished. We can contribute towards the Federation.

    If we want to be independent, I think, as the Chief Minister has realised long

Column: 3092

ago, it can only be through a merger with the Federation. If the Federation has all the forces ready, there is no need for us to build up forces ourselves in order to merge with it. Whilst we are not yet merged with the Federation, Britain will have to protect us. It is its duty, it has agreed to take on our external defence. When we are independent and join up with the Federation, our whole revenue can then be added to that of the Federation, which has already been developing an army, navy and air force.

    On the question of local youths, I do not want what I have said to be twisted. We want our local men to be useful and I said right at the outset this morning that we should convert all these forces into institutions producing useful people instead of just fighting men.

    Mr Seah Peng Chuan (Kampong Kapor): Mr Speaker, Sir, as one of the Independent Members, I wonder at the debate this morning on the defence services. The Hon. the Chief Minister has said that we must have local defence forces of our own; why then are we negotiating to surrender our Royal Malayan Navy to the Federation of Malaya? We are now spending 5 per cent of our expenditure per year on these forces. We know that in time to come we will be an independent country like the Federation or Indonesia. We must therefore have our own defence forces now, just as a precaution against any attack. Sir, the point is this, that we should have our own Singapore Regiment and other defence forces; we cannot surrender our navy to the Federation.

    Another thing is that training of the recruits has gone on for quite a long time. If we surrender the navy, all its personnel may become unemployed unless they will be allowed to cross the Causeway and become Federation citizens. If not, we should not transfer the navy.

    This is a matter which we must think of before we decide.

    Question on the amendment put, and negatived.

Column: 3093



    Mr Lee Choon Eng (Queenstown): Mr Speaker, Sir, before I move my amendment I would like some information from the Hon. the Chief Secretary. A provision of $5,500 was made for lockers this year, for the purchase of lockers. Now we are asked to provide another $2,750 to purchase lockers for next year. I would like to know whether there is an increase in the strength of personnel, how many lockers were purchased for what number of ratings, and how many lockers will be purchased next year out of the $2,750.

    Mr Stewart: Sir, this subhead provides $2,750 for lockers in which volunteers keep their clothing and valuables. The Malayan Royal Naval Volunteer Reserve originally in 1956 asked for $12,000 for the purpose. This sum was reduced in the 1957 Estimates to $5,500 and the provision of $2,750 in the 1958 Estimates represents the balance of the sum required to provide lockers for some 650 ratings. The lockers are likely to be made of wood and metal. The Member for Queenstown would probably like to know - or he probably knows already - that volunteers mostly come straight from their offices to, and change in, the ships. That is the reason why we would like to get this sum to complete the provision of lockers for 650 ratings.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am afraid the Hon. the Chief Secretary has not answered my point, which is whether the strength of ratings has so far been increased. He has not answered that. I also asked for the number of lockers purchased this year. What he said is that the sum is required to purchase lockers for 650 ratings. Is that the full strength of the navy, or are there extra men?

    Rather than delay the debate, I think I will move my amendment to reduce the figure. I now formally move, Sir,

    That the sum to be allotted for Head II be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 66 therein.

    The question is this, Sir, that although a sum of $12,000 was asked for in 1956, the Government thought fit to reduce it to $5,500. If the Government at the time thought that it should be reduced

Column: 3094

and the reduced sum was quite adequate for 1957, there should not be any reason why a further $2,750 should be voted for lockers next year.

    Another point is that the Chief Secretary said $12,000 was required and $2,750 is needed to complete the amount. I wonder at the mathematics of the Chief Secretary, that $5,500 plus $2,750 can make $12,000.

    Mr Stewart: Sir, I said that this was the balance that we require to complete providing lockers for volunteers in the M.R.N.V.R. You will notice in the Estimates also, Sir, there are a few new deckhands, and probably there has been an increase also in the number of ratings, which has now reached a maximum of 650.

    Question on the amendment put, and negatived.

    Head 12-

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: Mr Speaker, Sir, I move,

    That the sum to be allotted for Head 12 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (1) of subhead I therein.

    Sir, I believe that the Government has, as I will outline, turned a blind eye to film censorship, or is sheer lazy in this matter. The law that Government applies is a British Military Administration Proclamation; and up to now it has not been revised. Do we want to carry on with a law fixed by proclamation? Today we have an elected government and we should remove all these old laws made at the whim and fancy of single individuals. Government should look into the matter, repeal the B.M.A. Proclamation and introduce a new Bill in the Legislative Assembly.

    One peculiar thing about that B.M.A. Proclamation is that it seems to give - and Government seems to uphold it - protection to British films. There is a quota of 10 per cent for British films. A cinema can show whatever films it likes but 10 per cent of them must be British films. We in Singapore think that protection of this kind should be done away with, and that whoever wants to sell or exhibit films here should compete on the basis of merit and not on favouritism.

Column: 3095



10.45 a.m.

    I am bringing up this matter, too, because the law does not even allow the 10 per cent to be included for our own industry. I thought that this matter should have been brought up by the Labour Front but as I am a Singaporean, and want to protect local industries, I am voicing this for the local people. We have our own local film industry producing Malay pictures and probably others in the vernacular. Since we have our local industry coming up, with so many people aspiring to be "stars" (at least for Singapore, if not for East Asia), what protection is Government giving to it? Are we going to fix a quota for it, as we protect the British industry? Or are we going to allow it to compete with foreign producers and allow foreign exchange to be taken out of this country? If Government is serious about promoting anything local, it should consider very seriously ways and means of helping the local industry.

    At this point, I want to voice my opinion about the quality of many of the imported films, from whatever source. Many of them are of very low standard and I would urge the film censor to be a bit more free with the scissors, to cut out items which may teach the young people of Singapore to be more efficient in crime, to steal and rob, or to murder, and also items showing the other side of life which is more Western, showing customs and people in the West exhibiting themselves in a way that would be abominable according to Eastern standards. And if the film censor's scissors are a bit freer, I think we can have a cleaner Singapore.

    The Attorney-General (Mr E. P. Shanks): Mr Speaker, Sir, I should like to be able to help the hon. Member for Serangoon by giving him the exact date on which the Legislature of the Colony, the local Legislature, enacted the Film Censorship Ordinance. It was some years ago.

    The Chief Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, the hon. Member for Serangoon speaks of a 10 per cent quota for British films and, according to my notes, said that this 10 per cent is to be included for our local industry. English is indeed

Column: 3096

a difficult language and I am finding great difficulty in understanding what that means. Does he mean the 10 per cent to be included in the local industry, or really that films made locally should be included in the 10 per cent British quota?

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: On a point of explanation, Sir, 10 per cent of films shown have to be British, 90 per cent anything else. If you show a locally-produced film, that film is not included in that 10 per cent British quota but outside it. I mean that 10 per cent is for British films and nothing else, and I am asking what sort of protection our local films will get.

    The Chief Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, I now understand what he meant although I found great difficulty in doing so from his original speech. In regard to this 10 per cent British quota, I would give the hon. Member the assurance that the Government would look into this matter.

    Mr Stewart: Mr Speaker, Sir, with regard to the last point which the hon. Member for Serangoon made, on the question of the film censor using the scissors more, this question was also raised in the debate last year on the Estimates. It was then pointed out that film censorship is a somewhat difficult subject but that the censors are doing the best they can. I am sure that whatever remarks were made last year have been taken note of and not lost on those responsible for taking the difficult decisions as to which films to allow in and how far it is possible to make cuts in them without doing any damage.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Mr Speaker, speaking in support of the hon. Member for Serangoon regarding the low standard of the pictures shown here, I would comment on the peculiar way films are censored in Singapore. I have noticed on many occasions that a film banned in Singapore is, in a matter of a few weeks, heavily advertised and shown in Johore. I think this is due to lack of co-ordination between the censors here and in the Federation of

Column: 3097

Malaya. One censor thinks that a film should be banned whereas the other thinks that it should be shown in the interests of the public. I cannot see, Sir, why a picture should be banned in Singapore when it can be seen easily in Johore. The distance between Johore and Singapore is only a matter of 17 miles, and anyone can drive his car to Johore and see the banned picture.

    I would suggest that there should be more co-ordination between the two censors, that if a film is banned in Singapore it should be banned in Johore as well. I would not mind if it goes right up to Kuala Lumpur or Penang, because there is a great distance to Kuala Lumpur and Penang, but what is the difference between Singapore and Johore, that is until such time as the Prime Minister of the Federation introduces a causeway block? Until such a block is introduced, there is freedom of movement between Johore and Singapore. So I think that the people of Singapore do feel that it is funny for a picture to be banned in Singapore but be shown in Johore.

    Mr Stewart: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think the Member for Queenstown has completely misunderstood the position. There is one Board of Film Censors for both Singapore and the Federation of Malaya comprised of a Chairman, a Chinese member, a Malay member and an Indian member, together with an assistant censor. What the Member has not appreciated is that there are two Committees of Appeal, one for Singapore and the other for the Federation. Appeals from a decision of the censor to the Singapore Committee are in respect of films to be shown here in Singapore, whereas appeals in the Federation go to the Federation Committee of Appeal. There are two different Committees of Appeal but only one Censor, against whose decision people can appeal to the relevant Committee of Appeal.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Mr Speaker, Sir, I take it from the Chief Secretary that there is a Board of Film Censors comprising representatives from the Federation and Singapore. In the case

Column: 3098

of appeals, there are separate Committees for the Federation and Singapore. The Film Censors Board has representatives of the two states and is more or less a pan-Malayan department; I see that of the vote of $209,930, part is recoverable from the Federation. As it is more or less a pan-Malayan Board, when films are shown to it and not to the Appeals Committees, it should take into consideration whether a film should or should not be shown in Johore, rather than allow that film to go straight to the Film Appeals Committee.
